list_page_teaser: This gallery contains spiritual portraits of famous, real people.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
Here are a few images of real people.

Hopefully everyone will recognize these names and appreciate the ability to see their personalities.
story_html:
These images are based on some dvds I found at the Denver Public Library. I chose these individuals because their stories were readily available and believe most, if not all, visitors will recognize their names and have some knowledge of them.

I plan to add more portraits to this gallery soon. To keep up to date and learn when I post new images, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Woody Allen
image_list.subtitle_html: Comedian, Filmmaker, Auteur
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Born Allan Stewart Konigsberg, Woody has averaged putting out one film per year for fourty years.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Woody's dominant trait, his compassion and warmth.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he treats the actors and actresses in his films with compassion.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Woody's auxiliary trait, iNtuition: idealism; openness to ideas; preference for ideas over facts.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he is willing to make films of varying types, rather than stick to a tried and true genre (e.g., comedies).
image_list.story_intro_html: While he was still in high school, Woody Allen started writing one-liners for established comedians. This led to writing for ....
image_list.story_html:
While he was still in high school, Woody Allen started writing one-liners for established comedians. This led to writing for and even appearing on TV shows such as the Ed Sullivan Show and The Tonight Show.

In the 1960s he started doing stand-up. He hated it.

I kept saying, I'm not funny, I'm not a comic, you know, I can't do this, I hate it, I don't like the hours, I'm shy, you know I don't like standing in front of an audience. I mean there was nothing about it I liked. I kept saying I want to quit, I want to quit.

It sounds to me like he might be a bit Introverted.

Woody went on to be a playwright, and this led to filmmaking. Writing a screenplay led to work as a director, and this led to him writing, directing, and starring in a series of successful films.

It turned out that like Hitchcock and Truffaut, Woody worked best as an auteur, someone who had complete control over all creative aspects of a film. But making the shift from comedy to drama proved to be more difficult than expected.

It's harder for me, and I embarrass myself more readily, but I get more pleasure out of failing in a project that I am enthused over, than in succeeding in a project that I know I can do well.

A more pragmatic person would have more Yellow in their spiritual portrait — and probably more money in their bank account. As an INFP myself, I took my time with college, changing majors a few times and even quiting for awhile.

So I can certainly understand where he's coming from. As The Beatles so aptly put it: Can't Buy Me Love.

I've been working on the quantity theory. I feel if I keep making films and just keep making them, every once in awhile I'll get lucky and one will come out. And that's exactly what happens.

And that, dear reader, is exactly what's been going on with me and this spiritual portrait idea, which I am presenting on this site for the umpteenth time!

There are a lot of surprises that happen between writing it, doing it, and seeing it on the screen. Most surprises are negative. Most surprises are, that you thought something was good or funny, and it's not.... Cause it's not easy. If it was easy, it wouldn't be fun, it wouldn't be valuable.... There's a big difference between what you set out to make, and what you make, almost every time.

Make no mistake: if this site is successful this time around, it will be in great part to the inspiration and ideas I've gotten from all of the more down-to-earth pragmatic people I've met over the past few years at the various meetups around town. Many of these friends will undoubtedly have more Yellow in their spiritual portraits, but like Woody I love what I do — and that's more important to people like us than the numbers in our bank accounts!

This spiritual portrait is based on the two-disk DVD boxed set, Woody Allen: A Documentary.

image_list.title: Edward Snowden
image_list.subtitle_html: System Administrator, Whistleblower
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Edward Snowden achieved notoriety by releasing classified information detailing how the United States government collects information on all citizens.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents X's dominant trait, his idealism and preference for ideas over facts.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  They demonstrate this trait in their ....
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents X's auxiliary trait, his cool-headedness and preference for logic over emotion.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  They demonstrate this trait in their ....
image_list.story_intro_html: I have mixed feelings about Ed Snowden, so it may be best to ....
image_list.story_html:
I have mixed feelings about Ed Snowden, so it may be best to let him describe himself in his own words.

We are building the greatest weapon for oppression in the history of man, yet its directors exempt themselves from accoutability.... I appreciate your [Laura Poitras' and Glenn Greenwald's] concern for my safety, but I already know how this will end for me, and I accept the risk.

As a firmly decisive and logical person, it's easy to see how he could feel he had no choice but to do what he did. I can almost hear his conscience saying They taught me one thing in school, now they're doing something else in real life! Hellooooo! This does not compute!

I have to admire his courage and idealism, but it's important to stress that I created this site to help people visualize personalities, not to convert people to one political ideology or another.

So, for me, it all comes down to state power against the people's ability to meaningfully oppose that power. And I'm sitting there, uh, every day getting paid to design methods to amplify that state power.

As an idealist, I enjoy seeing idealism in others, and find it interesting to learn his four-letter-type matches that of the contemptuous Joffrey Baratheon. In addition to being idealistic, he's obviously fearless, and after watching the movie I can't help but be glad he did what he did.

I wonder how he feels about his actions now that the dust has settled and he's living in exile.

These are public issues, these are not my issues you know, these are everybody's issues. I'm not afraid of you, you know. You're not going to bully me into silence like you've done to everybody else. And if nobody else is gonna do it, I will, and hopefully when I'm gone, whatever you do to me, there will be somebody else who'll do the same thing.

It is important to realize that, because this personality profile is based only on the film Citizenfour, it may not be completely accurate.

Although he doesn't show it outwardly, it's obvious that Ed was under a great deal of stress during this time. Therefore it may not accurately show who he is in his typical day-to-day life during less stressful times.

If you would like to learn more about Ed Snowden, and perhaps support him with a donation, visit his site at edwardsnowden.com.

This spiritual portrait is based only on what I learned about Edward from watching Laura Poitras' movie about him, Citizenfour.

image_list.title: Eleanor Roosevelt
image_list.subtitle_html: First Lady and Wife of FDR
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Eleanor Roosevelt's spiritual portrait shows she is compassionate and idealistic.  These qualities show why she showed concern for and wanted to help others, especially those who were disadvantaged, have a better future.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Eleanor's dominant trait, her warmth and compassion.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  She demonstrated this trait in the way she cared for people, in her family and in all of America as a whole.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Eleanor's auxiliary trait, her idealism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  She demonstrated this trait in the way she would always try to help others work for and have a better future.
image_list.story_intro_html: An orphan at 10, Eleanor Roosevelt's story is quite inspirational. She was a prolific writer and following are some quotes that ....
image_list.story_html:
An orphan at 10, Eleanor Roosevelt's story is quite inspirational. She was a prolific writer and following are some quotes should motivate those who don't know much about her to learn more.

Do what you feel in your heart to be right — for you'll be criticized anyway. You'll be damned if you do, and damned if you don't.

Pithy and filled with positive energy, she was full of words to remember and phrases to live by:

You can often change your circumstances by changing your attitude.
Happiness is not a goal ... it's a by-product of a life well lived.
No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.
It takes as much energy to wish as it does to plan.

I've saved the best — from my point of view, anyway — for last:

You gain strength, courage and confidence by every experience in which you really stop to look fear in the face. You are able to say to yourself, I have lived through this horror. I can take the next thing that comes along. You must do the thing you think you cannot do.

It's scary to create a site like this! What if someone hacks it? What if people make fun of me for trying to draw personalities? I see the look in the eyes of people when I tell them about it. What if someone steals my idea? What if this, what if that, what if...??? Yes I know they are just a bunch of squares! Like, duh!

Thank you, Eleanor for sharing the key to your courage with me — and everyone else!

There are many, many more of her quotes online. The wikiquote site is a great place to start. Enjoy!

This spiritual portrait is based on Ken Burns' film The Roosevelts: An Intimate Portrait. In addition to Eleanor, this work covers her uncle Theodore and her husband Franklin, and spans seven DVDs. I enjoyed watching it (twice!) and recommend it highly!

image_list.title: Fidel Castro
image_list.subtitle_html: 17th President of Cuba - Dec. 2, 1976 - Feb. 24, 2008
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Fidel Castro's spiritual portrait shows he is decisive, passionate, a bit idealistic, and quite versatile.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in Fidel's spiritual portrait represents his dominant personality trait, his passion.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Castro demonstrated this trait in the passion he had for Cuba.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in Fidel's spiritual portrait represents his auxiliary personality trait, his idealism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this trait in the way he embraced revolutionary Marxist-Leninist ideals.

image_list.title: Imelda Marcos
image_list.subtitle_html: 10th First Lady of the Philippines - Dec. 30, 1965 - Feb. 25, 1986
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Imelda Marcos's spiritual portrait shows she prefers a world of ideas and idealism to the world of facts.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in Imelda's spiritual portrait represents her dominant personality trait, her openness to ideas.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in Imelda's spiritual portrait represents her auxiliary personality trait, her warmth and passion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  She demonstrated this trait in some of the projects she pursued while First Lady of the Philippines.
image_list.story_html:
This spiritual portrait of Imelda Marcos, the infamous First Lady of the Philippines, reflects her fairly strong preferences for ideas and emotion (over facts and logic) with ample amounts of Blue and Red (and very little Yellow and Green).

It may seem surprising that someone who put so much emphasis on beauty — ostensibly a surface quality — would be an idealist. It turns out that Imelda actually equates beauty with god and love:

It is not expensive to be beautiful. It takes only a little effort, to be presentable, and beautiful. But, it takes some effort. And E for effort. And unfortunately, people think of beauty as luxury; of beauty as frivolity, no! Or extravagant. Beauty is a discipline. Beauty is art, is harmony, in the ideological sense. And in the theological sense beauty is god and love made real.
 — From Imelda, 2003.

Given her point of view, it's easy to see how Imelda's obsession with appearances in general and shoes (I did not have three thousand pairs of shoes, I had one thousand and sixty.) in particular is based on idealism. And from her point of view this infatuation is based not on selfishness but on her concern for the poor, little people in her country.

I am my little people's star and slave. When I go out into the barrios, I get dressed because I know my little people want to see a star. Other presidents' wives have gone to the barrios wearing housedresses and slippers. That's not what people want to see. People want someone they can love, someone to set an example.
 — From The LA Times, 1980.

The movie about her life, Imelda: Power, Myth, Illusion, directed by Ramona S. Diaz, is an enjoyable, enlightening, and nicely balanced view of her before, during, and after her time as First Lady of the Philippines. It includes a scene in which she reads from her book — a book she introduces with a rather surprising yet refreshing bit of humility.

There is a Facebook page for her book and a video about it on youtube.com. Following is a quote she reads from Circles of Life in the movie:

All the things that you see around you, they become the elements of your infrastructure. But they can only be good as they are beautiful, and beauty is in the landscape of your heart. Do not leave it there. Paint it, shape it, build it, let it flow from within you, in everything you do or touch. It is easy to be beautiful, because it is magical.
 — Quoted from Circles of Life by Imelda Marcos in the movie Imelda, 2003.

It's rather difficult to believe that her husband, Ferdinand Marcos, ruled the Philippines as a dictator for over twenty years, declaring a period of martial law starting in 1972 and running for almost ten years, amid accusations of human rights abuses such as abductions, torture, and murder.

Thanks to Imelda's idealistic viewpoint, she can have her own interpretation of these events. For example, in the movie she has this to say about the assassination of her husband's political rival Benigno Aquino Jr.:

The events have proven that we, the Marcoses, Ferdinand and Imelda, were ultimately the victims in the assassination of [Senator Benigno Ninoy] Aquino [Jr.].
 — From Imelda, 2003.

That seems to be stretching things a bit, but what can one expect from someone who uses her own name to create a word — Imeldific — to describe herself.

This spiritual portrait is based mainly on the movie about her life, Imelda: Power, Myth, Illusion, directed by Ramona S. Diaz.
